阅读我们最近对乌克兰战争的更多报道

; Thu, 27 Jul 2023 11:17:56 GMT /内容/6dcddo7e96s5miv5u35eirrquflvrg6n https://www.economist.com/international/2023/07/27/the-ukrainian-army-commits-new-forces-in-a-big-southward-push Russia is attacking Ukraine’s agricultural exports

联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯上周哀叹道，“今天的决定将对世界各地有需要的人们造成打击。”他谴责的伤害是俄罗斯拒绝了一项已有一年的协议，该协议允许乌克兰在黑海港口出口粮食作物，尽管有海上封锁。古特雷斯警告称，由此引发的谷物价格飞涨将导致许多人挨饿。本周，俄罗斯对乌克兰的粮食出口进行了更实际的打击，轰炸了敖德萨周边的粮食出口港口。

7 月 22 日晚，针对市中心附近码头的一系列导弹不分青红皂白地齐射，击中了该市的一座大教堂。 7 月 19 日，又有 6 万吨粮食在另一次轰炸中被毁。 7 月 24 日，俄罗斯瞄准了多瑙河上的一个港口雷尼（不在协议范围内），乌克兰一直通过该港口经罗马尼亚出口粮食。

在俄罗斯入侵之前，乌克兰每年出口约 4500 万吨谷物，其中约 90% 通过敖德萨和黑海其他港口。粮食交易实施当年，通过敖德萨港口出口了近 3300 万吨。现在这种情况已经停止了。

公路、铁路和内河驳船的出口一直在增加，但来自敖德萨的分析师汉娜·谢莱斯特(Hanna Shelest)表示，没有足够的能力来替代海运。不管怎样，她补充道，这些替代方案“在物流方面要贵几倍，而且速度更慢”。陆路出口还导致邻国粮食价格暴跌，激怒了波兰等其他友好国家的农民。

战前农业占乌克兰GDP的10%以上，就业率近15%。许多农场仍在运营。小麦收割工作正在进行中。向日葵将在初秋绽放，几周后将迎来玉米。俄罗斯的轰炸摧毁了乌克兰的大部分储存能力，因此迫切需要为乌克兰的出口找到新的出路。 ■

; Thu, 27 Jul 2023 10:27:56 GMT /内容/lv5o9l26mqa351i6ura85ovr11ud41us https://www.economist.com/international/2023/07/27/ Russia-is-attacking-ukraines-agriculture-exports Is Ukraine’s offensive stalling?

阅读我们最近对乌克兰战争的更多报道

; Tue, 25 Jul 2023 18:48:44 GMT /内容/u63vccf764smnho3it51k4t7bllthmem https://www.economist.com/international/2023/07/25/is-ukraines-offective-stalling What if China and India became friends?

中国的统治者喜欢看不起印度。他们蔑视其动荡的政治、破旧的基础设施和贫困。 印度的目光充满了恐惧和嫉妒，希望得到平等对待，但徒劳无功。现在跨喜马拉雅关系的结构正在发生变化。最近的边境流血事件表明敌意不断加剧。但蓬勃发展的经济关系却讲述了一个不同的故事，这可能会给美国及其盟友带来麻烦。

1924 年 4 月，当印度最受尊敬的诗人访问中国时，中国知识分子并不为所动。罗宾德拉纳特·泰戈尔作为第一位非欧洲诺贝尔文学奖得主而受到全球的欢迎。他强烈批评英国在印度的统治，希望在亚洲最古老的文明之间重建古老的文化纽带。

然而，对于中国领先的思想家来说，他关于复兴东方价值观和灵性的呼吁听起来很空洞。他们认为，中国人只能通过向西方学习并拒绝自己的传统文化来抵抗西方。中国共产党联合创始人陈独秀写道，中国的年轻人不应该“印度化”。 “除非，也就是说，他们希望自己的棺材有一天能躺在殖民国家脚下的土地上。”

近一个世纪后，中国官员和学者对印度的看法仍然充满了蔑视。他们说，只要看看数据就可以了。 1947 年独立时，印度的人均GDP高于中国（按购买力计算）。但到了 20 世纪 90 年代初，中国在这一措施和许多其他措施方面取得了进展。到2022年，两国人口大致相等，但中国的经济规模是其三倍多。

中国的将军们也倾向于忽视印度。人们自豪地回忆起1962年中国在边境战争中取得的压倒性胜利。他们还将中国目前的国产现代武器库与印度持续依赖俄罗斯进口的武器进行了对比。 “印度在未来20-30年内不可能赶上中国，”中国军事科学院赵小卓大校说。

然而，中印关系的基本面——军事和经济——现在正在发生变化，迫使世界上最大的民主国家和最大的独裁国家重新评估彼此以及与世界其他国家打交道的方式。美国及其盟国官员希望，印度与中国持续的边境摩擦正在不可逆转地将其推向一个决心限制中国实力的民主联盟。问题是：如果他们找到办法搁置边界争端怎么办？

首先考虑军事方程式。自 2008 年签署民用核合作协议以来，印度一直在与美国走得更近。但自从印度与中国边境发生一系列冲突以来，两国的结盟速度加快了，其中包括 2020 年发生的一场冲突，造成 20 名印度士兵和至少 4 名士兵死亡中国的。这是自 1967 年以来最血腥的冲突，结束了边境地区长达 30 年的相对稳定时期。

此后，印度武装部队的重心发生了历史性转移，从巴基斯坦转移出去。他们已向与中国接壤的边境调派了约7万名士兵以及战斗机和地对空导弹。他们还扩大了与美国及其盟国，特别是澳大利亚和日本的联合演习。美国也为印度边防部队提供了一些情报和高空训练。

乌克兰战争又带来了刺激。印度指挥官对他们对俄罗斯武器的依赖感到担忧。印度希望购买先进的美国武器并在印度生产更多武器。 6 月，印度总理纳伦德拉·莫迪 (Narendra Modi) 在华盛顿达成了购买武装无人机以及在印度联合制造战斗机发动机的协议，取得了进展。

中国在边境问题上的具体动机尚不清楚。它可能是对印度最近修建的道路做出的反应，这使得更广泛的巡逻成为可能，也可能是对解决谈判缺乏进展感到沮丧。或者它可能想惩罚印度早些时候与美国的和解，暴露印度军队的相对弱点，并表明他们不能依赖美国的帮助。

印度陆军北方司令部前司令迪彭德拉·辛格·胡达 (Deependra Singh Hooda) 表示，中国认为自己与印度处于另一个联盟，与美国直接竞争。该司令部负责监管部分中国边境。中国传达的信息似乎是：“你们不是中国人民解放军的对手……你们只是一场杂耍。”

一个二边三角形

无论出于何种原因，中国领导人习近平似乎认为其后果是可控的。印度的重新部署意味着，如果中国尝试再次入侵边境，它可能会给中国带来更大的成本。但中国将在多年内保持足够的军事优势，以阻止印度试图挽回任何明显的损失（见图1）。尽管印度可以在某些领域帮助美国，特别是在印度洋，但它不愿结成正式联盟，也不太可能加入台湾或南中国海的冲突。

尽管如此，随着美国加大限制中国实力的力度，习近平有强烈的动机去稳定边境。莫迪先生也是如此。他似乎热衷于淡化边境问题，因为他知道自己几乎没有军事选择。他对于任何明显的领土损失都不愿引起国内关注。妥协似乎是可能的。经过18轮军事指挥官会谈后，部队已从5个热点地区撤出，建立了双方均不巡逻的“缓冲区”。仍然存在两个主要热点。

中国正在推动新一轮会谈，并敦促印度不要让边界问题定义双边关系。印度外交部长苏杰生 (Subrahmanyam Jaishankar) 7 月 14 日在雅加达会见了中国外长，讨论了边境问题。最近几周他强调，如果没有和平稳定的边界，正常的商业关系就无法恢复。

然而，对经济形势的调查使印度的此类警告得到了正确的看待。中国和印度之间的贸易在其现代历史的大部分时间里都是微不足道的。但到 2020 年，货物贸易已飙升至 880 亿美元，其中中国顺差达 460 亿美元，成为印度最大的贸易伙伴（见图 2）。中国也已成为重要的投资来源国，特别是在技术、房地产和基础设施方面。中国品牌也很受欢迎。 Oppo和小米是最畅销的手机之一。

2020 年的边境冲突使这一切都面临风险。印度禁止了约 320 个中国应用程序，对几家中国公司发起税务突击搜查，并出台了要求印度政府批准中国投资的新规定。印度官员表示，此后他们已拒绝了 157 份相关申请。然而，2021 年双边货物贸易增长了 43%，去年增长了 8.6%。中国的投资也在寻找途径，有时是通过新加坡。 Shein 是一家中国在线时尚公司，其应用程序曾在 2020 年被印度禁止，但该公司很快将与印度最大的私营公司信实工业 (Reliance Industries) 合作在印度重新推出。

印度官员希望减少对中国进口产品的依赖，并吸引更多来自其他地方的投资，特别是寻求中国替代品的大型跨国制造商。 “我们需要停止寻找中国解决方案，”印度外交部长苏杰生 (Jaishankar) 今年 5 月表示。 “印度的增长不能建立在中国的效率之上。”

不过，许多印度商界领袖私下预测，如果印度政府要实现发展基础设施和制造业的目标，未来几年将依赖中国进口。例如，印度制药业约 70% 的活性成分依赖中国。

从理论上讲，这确实使印度容易受到中国对其他国家施加的经济胁迫。但随着经济放缓、人口减少以及西方国家日益敌对，中国的影响力可能正在减弱。中国企业现在将今年人口超过中国的印度视为重要的增长源，高盛预测，到2075年，印度GDP将仅次于中国。

其他领域也存在经济协同效应。印度是总部位于北京的亚洲基础设施投资银行的最大借款国，该银行是中国于2016年设立的，旨在替代西方主导的贷款机构。印度还是总部位于上海的新开发银行的成员，该银行由巴西、俄罗斯、印度、中国和南非（金砖国家）于 2015 年组建。

热烈的经济交流并不能保证避免进一步的边境流血甚至战争。这两个国家的领导人都以民族主义和历史恩怨为食。其他紧张局势包括中国在南亚日益增长的影响力、在对印度至关重要的河流上游筑坝，以及印度为西藏精神领袖达赖喇嘛提供的庇护所。

尽管如此，不断发展的商业关系将在双方的决策中发挥越来越重要的作用。拉吉夫·甘地1988年作为印度总理访华后三十年所取得的稳定边界问题的成果，将为两国留下足够的合作空间。两国都希望在全球治理中发挥更大作用，拒绝西方对人权和气候变化的批评，并对伊斯兰极端主义表示共同担忧。两人都拒绝谴责俄罗斯入侵乌克兰。

同样值得注意的是，在最近的边境冲突之前，莫迪似乎决心与习近平建立密切关系，并于 2014 年采取了不同寻常的举措，在家乡古吉拉特邦接待了习近平。印度和中国有着相似的愿望、挑战和共同点。莫迪先生次年在北京表示，这是一个机遇。 “在我们这个时代的全球不确定性中，我们可以加强彼此的进步。”

这样的前景可能不会令美国人和其他将印度视为制衡中国的人感到高兴。这也不是泰戈尔在1924年敦促中国拒绝西方唯物主义并“将人类灵魂从机器的牢笼中解放出来”时所想的。但这可能是亚洲巨头之间建立可持续、互利关系的更现实的道路。 ■

; Wed, 19 Jul 2023 17:59:05 GMT /内容/kc44bjfhd4f8j99lm2b44phuarvuu6cp https://www.economist.com/international/2023/07/19/what-if-china-and-india-became-friends What would Europe do if Trump won?

唐纳德·特朗普关于乌克兰战争的花言巧语在战场上飘荡，如同俄罗斯炸弹笼罩的黑暗。 “我希望每个人都停止死亡。他们快死了。俄罗斯人和乌克兰人，”他在五月宣称。如果明年连任总统，他将“在 24 小时内”结束战争。如何？他没有明说，但他的话暗示停止对乌克兰的军事援助，让俄罗斯保留其入侵的成果。

如果是这样，“不受约束的特朗普”的回归——比他的第一个任期更怨恨、更有组织、更少约束——可能对乌克兰来说是一场灾难。从其他方面来看，这对欧洲来说可能是一场灾难。他很可能从他的第一个任期开始就发出离开北约的威胁。他将在国会面临严厉的反对。但联盟依赖于信任。仅仅暗示他不会为盟友而战就可能彻底摧毁俄罗斯正在试图的欧洲秩序。

在乔·拜登总统的领导下，美国向乌克兰提供了大部分军事援助，并领导西方做出反应。如果这场战争显示了美国保护的价值，那么特朗普的民粹主义可能会证明它的消失速度有多快。

因此，欧洲各国政府面临着三种恐惧：俄罗斯的攻击、中国的经济削弱以及美国的放弃。法国对这三个问题给出了明确的答案：欧洲“战略自主”。 5 月，法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙 (Emmanuel Macron) 在布拉迪斯拉发发表讲话时提出了一个难以启齿的问题：“（美国）政府会永远保持不变吗？没有人能说清楚，我们不能将我们的集体安全和稳定委托给美国选民的选择。”他认为，欧洲人需要能够保卫自己，不仅在军事上，而且在经济上。

批评者认为此类呼吁是企图切断欧洲与美国的联系。但如果美国放松欧洲怎么办？法国官员认为，随着美国转向国内、外交政策聚焦于中国，跨大西洋分离已经开始。特朗普先生只是这一趋势最残酷的体现。他们指出，在贸易方面，拜登的保护主义程度并不比特朗普低。在欧洲的强烈抗议中，他告诉马克龙，他“不知道”《通货膨胀削减法案》中的巨额绿色补贴会威胁欧洲的工业。

他们认为，美国的首要任务是与中国的竞争。迟早，即使是拜登先生也会希望减少在欧洲的工作，而将重点放在亚洲。如果台湾爆发危机，可能会更早。未来的民主党或共和党总统之间的区别可能只是美国从欧洲转向的速度和程度。大多数欧洲政府并不完全同意这一分析——美国对欧洲的军事承诺正在增加——但很少有人忽视这一点。

如果被抛弃，欧洲还能自力更生吗？理论上是的。欧洲北约盟国已实现工业化，人口近 6 亿。他们拥有近 200 万人的武装人员和数十年的合作经验。其中两个国家——英国和法国——拥有核武器并拥有联合国安理会常任理事国席位。

诚然，北约得到了美国实力的支持，美国的军费占北约军费总额的三分之二。美国30个盟国中只有10个能够实现今年国防开支占GDP 2%的目标。即使这样也应该足以抵御俄罗斯。智库斯德哥尔摩国际和平研究所估计，欧洲盟国在 2022 年总共花费了 3330 亿美元。相比之下，俄罗斯的支出可能为 860 亿美元。考虑到其更大的购买力，将该金额增加一倍或三倍仍然存在很大差距。但欧洲并没有采取集体行动。它的开支分散在数十个实力往往不足的陆军、空军和海军上。其中大部分都流向了备受宠爱的民族工业。

智库欧洲外交关系委员会（ ECFR ）最近发表的一篇论文指出，从根本上来说，欧洲人遭受着“附庸化”的痛苦。欧洲人在优先事项上没有达成一致。他们彼此之间也没有足够的信任来决定应该采取什么更大的自主权。欧洲两个最重要的机构——北约和欧盟——并不完全契合。英国、挪威和土耳其等重要盟友均处于欧盟之外。集体防御是北约的事，由美国指挥。经济政策主要由欧盟制定，欧盟的成立是为了与军事联盟对立。尤其是法国，一直试图利用它来制衡美国。

一个人去吗？

尽管北约峰会在 7 月 11 日承诺“只要需要”就支持乌克兰，如果美国放弃乌克兰，欧洲人还会继续战争吗？一些外交官表示他们会这样做；但也有一些外交官表示他们会这样做。许多人对此表示怀疑。欧洲的核武库比美国的核武库规模更小、消耗更严重。它的国防工业也遭受着与美国类似的弊病——按时生产处于和平时期的水平——而且缺乏规模。意大利智库国际研究所的娜塔莉·托奇表示，矛盾的是，随着各国争相从美国、以色列、韩国和其他国家购买现成的工具包，乌克兰战争使情况变得更糟。

法国回避了德国主导的防空天盾项目，因为它依赖非欧洲供应商。德国官员反驳说，法国将战略自主视为利用德国资金支持法国企业的一种方式。尽管如此，还是取得了一些进展。欧盟正在为合作性武器项目提供激励措施，使用共同基金来支付军用物资，并推动企业在一年内向乌克兰供应 100 万发火炮。

北约前助理秘书长、 ECFR的卡米尔·格兰德 (Camille Grand) 表示，如果特朗普让美国完全退出北约，欧洲人将试图接管其机制，而不是将欧盟变成一个军事联盟。欧洲人必须填补美国在欧洲的 85,000 多名军队所填补的缺口，其中包括总部人员和 22 个作战营（大约与英国总数大致相同）。他们还必须采购美国大量供应的昂贵的“推动者”，例如航空运输和加油、太空资产和ISR （情报、监视和侦察）。格兰德先生相信，所有这一切可能需要欧洲十年的时间才能实现。

领导力将是一个问题。即使在最好的情况下，跨国决策也很困难，在军事事务上更是如此。欧洲缺乏一位领导人来取代美国霸主。尽管德国承诺增强其军力，但它仍秉持和平主义。由于脱欧，英国与欧洲事务半脱节。法国渴望领导一个更强大的欧洲，但遭到广泛不信任。

然后是核威慑。俄罗斯拥有近6000枚核弹头；英国和法国各约200-300人。格兰德认为，如果没有美国，欧洲核大国将不得不重新考虑其库存、理论以及与剩余盟友的合作。

至于经济层面的自治，欧盟已经取得了显着进展。在布鲁塞尔，它有时被称为“开放战略自主”，以表明对世界的开放。欧洲人正在逐渐将更多的经济决策集中在欧盟内部。在经历了从大流行期间疫苗短缺到俄罗斯入侵等一系列冲击之后，他们有充分的理由这样做。

最引人注目的成功是欧洲不再依赖俄罗斯的石油和天然气。来自美国和其他地方的替代供应以及欧盟内部能源市场（允许天然气和电力跨境交易）帮助了这一转变。欧盟新的经济武器库中有很大一部分是针对中国的。即将出台的“反胁迫”文书允许采取贸易报复措施，以防止立陶宛重蹈中国在立陶宛向台湾倾斜后的欺凌行为。新规定加强了对外国人投资的审查。与美国一样，国家和欧盟的补贴旨在促进半导体生产和绿色能源。欧洲正在与美国合作，实现关键矿产供应多元化，并限制敏感技术的对外投资。

对马克龙来说，这些举措是战略自主的“基石”。 “今天意识形态之战已经胜利，”他相信。然而，两种模式正在争夺欧洲和马克龙本人的灵魂。好的版本认为，欧洲应该增强自身实力，更有能力捍卫与美国的共同价值观和利益。坏的做法是法国戴高乐主义的传统，它试图将欧洲从美国手中拉开，并建立一个与之竞争的地缘政治极点。

在布拉迪斯拉发，马克龙的善良天使占了上风，他主张欧洲承担更多的国防负担。他来了个180度大转弯，支持乌克兰加入北约和欧盟东扩。然而一个月前，在访问北京后，他表现出了更糟糕的本性。他说，欧洲绝不能卷入中美竞争和“不属于我们的”台湾危机。此后，马克龙先生态度有所转变，派出一艘军舰通过台湾海峡。然而，他削弱了一项未宣布的协议，激怒了许多欧洲领导人：作为美国帮助击退俄罗斯的回报，欧洲应该支持其盟友遏制中国。

美国智库布鲁金斯学会的康斯坦泽·施特尔岑米勒表示，特朗普的当选将是一场“预言中的灾难”。很少有欧洲领导人能对此给出好的答案。许多人忽视了它；其他人则祈祷特朗普的破坏性不会像人们担心的那么大，或许会受到国会和五角大楼的克制。有人谈到要争取他的温和派追随者。另一家智库卡内基国际和平基金会的索菲亚·贝施预测，许多人会争先恐后地与他建立“双边”关系。他们可能会诉诸奉承，例如波兰将基地重新命名为“特朗普堡”的短暂计划，或者购买更多美国武器和其他东西来为他提供“好交易”。

一个问题是，特朗普的当选可能会在多大程度上推动欧洲极右翼的小特朗普。民意调查显示，德国另类选择党与德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨领导的社会民主党旗鼓相当。与此同时，在法国，人们越来越担心全国集会领袖马琳·勒庞 (Marine Le Pen) 可能会在 2027 年成为总统。两党都与俄罗斯关系密切，并批评西方对乌克兰的支持。正如拜登证明美国的力量可以团结欧洲人一样，特朗普也可能会展示其分裂欧洲人的力量。

人们常说，北约的目的是“阻止苏联、阻止美国、阻止德国”。或许战略自主权也能起到类似的作用。如果它能产生更多的军事能力，当美国转向亚洲时，它将让欧洲更好地掌控自己的安全——并在这个伟大盟友变得敌对时提供对冲。事实上，这可能是驳斥特朗普贪图便宜的指控并向美国展示欧洲价值的最佳方式。如果做得好，这可能有助于将俄罗斯拒之门外，将美国拒之门外，将中国拒之门外，同时将北约拒之门外。 ■

; Wed, 21 Jun 2023 20:32:59 GMT /内容/i2adps5v78bhaejocu0ksk7ivh3d9vh7 https://www.economist.com/international/2023/06/21/nato-is-agonising-over-whether-to-let-ukraine-join India’s diaspora is bigger and more influential than any in history

印度刚刚超过中国，成为世界上人口最多的国家，人口超过 14 亿。更重要的是，它的移民数量比中国同龄人更多，也更成功。自2010年以来，印度侨民规模一直位居世界第一，是印度政府的强大资源。

根据联合国2020 年的最新估计，当今全球有 2.81 亿移民（通常被定义为居住在出生国以外的人），其中近 1800 万是印度人（见图 1）。墨西哥移民是第二大群体，人数约为 1120 万。海外华人达到1050万。

了解印度人如何以及为何在海外取得胜利，而中国人则倾向于散播猜疑，可以阐明地缘政治断层线。比较这两个群体也揭示了印度取得的成就的程度。侨民的胜利既提升了印度的形象，也让印度总理纳伦德拉·莫迪受益。

移民与祖国的联系比在国外出生的后代更紧密，因此在他们的第二故乡和出生地之间建立了重要的联系。 2022 年，印度的汇入汇款创下近 1080 亿美元的纪录，约占GDP的 3%，超过任何其他国家。拥有人脉、语言技能和专业知识的海外印度人促进了跨境贸易和投资。

大量第二代、第三代和第四代中国人生活在国外，特别是在东南亚、美国和加拿大。但在许多富裕国家，包括美国和英国，印度出生的人口超过了中国出生的人口。

印度出生的移民遍布世界各地（见图 2），其中 270 万人居住在美国，超过 835,000 人居住在英国，720,000 人居住在加拿大，579,000 人居住在澳大利亚。年轻的印度人涌向中东，那里的低技能建筑和酒店业工作报酬更高。阿拉伯联合酋长国有 350 万印度移民，沙特阿拉伯有 250 万印度移民（联合国将印度公民视为印度出生人口的代表）。更多人居住在非洲以及亚洲和加勒比地区的其他地区。

印度拥有成为领先的人才输出国的基本要素：大量的年轻人和一流的高等教育。印度人对英语的掌握，这是英国殖民统治的遗产，可能也有帮助。美国智库移民政策研究所 ( mpi ) 的数据显示，在美国五岁以上的印度移民中，只有 22% 的人表示自己的英语能力有限，而中国移民的这一比例为 57%。

事情本来的样子

自 1947 年印度独立以来，出现了几波向富裕国家移民的浪潮，使得海外侨民的数量和实力不断增长。第一个是在第二次世界大战后的几年里，涉及主要来自古吉拉特邦和旁遮普邦的低技能工人。许多人前往面临严重劳动力短缺的英国。他们在艰苦的地方工作，例如纺织厂和其他工业设备。许多在殖民时期举家作为契约劳工移居东非的印度人后来也去了西部。 1965年，美国通过彻底修改移民法，成功吸引了大批人才。禁止印度公民的配额被取消，有利于高技术移民的新规则出台。澳大利亚和加拿大随后效仿，出台了一批类似的法规。

随着印度侨民的增长，它也变得更加多样化。越来越多来自贫困和边缘化背景的印度人移居国外。华盛顿智库卡内基国际和平基金会 2020 年发布的一项调查显示，在认同种姓群体的印度裔美国人中， 17% 的人认为自己是低种姓。移民不再主要来自古吉拉特邦和旁遮普邦。南印度人正在成群结队地移民。美国驻南部城市海得拉巴的领事馆是美国在南亚最大的前哨基地。与此同时，美国发展最快的语言是泰卢固语，几乎只在印度南部使用。

大脑在移动

随着未来几十年印度人口的增长，印度人民将继续移居海外寻找有利可图的工作并躲避酷暑。富裕国家的移民规则会筛选那些能够从事需要更多员工的职业的毕业生，例如医学和信息技术。 2022 年，美国 73% 的H-1B签证（颁发给计算机科学家等“专业职业”技术工人）由印度出生的人获得。

印度许多最优秀、最聪明的人似乎都做好了移民的准备。印度政府前经济顾问阿文德·萨勃拉曼尼安 (Arvind Subramanian) 表示，用经济术语来说，他们是“高度积极选择的移民”。考虑一下哈佛商学院的 Prithwiraj Choudhury、马萨诸塞大学阿默斯特分校的 Ina Ganguli 和布里斯托大学的 Patrick Gaule 即将在《发展经济学杂志》上发表的一篇论文的研究结果。它分析了 2010 年参加印度理工学院（该国精英工程学校）竞争激烈的入学考试的学生的成绩。八年后，研究人员发现，在 1,000 名表现最好的学生中，有 36% 移居国外，这一比例上升到62% 跻身 100 名最佳之列。大多数去了美国。

Another study looked at the top 20% of researchers in artificial intelligence (defined as those who had papers accepted for a competitive conference in 2019). It found that 8% did their first degree in India. But only a tiny number of researchers now work there.

In America almost 80% of the Indian-born population over school age have at least an undergraduate degree, according to number-crunching by Jeanne Batalova at the mpi. Just 50% of the Chinese-born population and 30% of the total population can say the same. It is a similar story in Australia, where almost two-thirds of the Indian-born population over school age, half the Chinese-born and just one-third of the total population have a bachelor's or higher degree. Other rich countries do not collect comparable data. But looking at the figures that are available, the same pattern seems to hold almost everywhere.

Joseph Nye, a Harvard professor who coined the term “soft power“ more than three decades ago, notes that such power is not automatically created by the mere presence of a diaspora. “But if you have people in the diaspora who are successful and create a positive image of the country from which they came, that helps their native country.” And, as he adds, “India has a lot of very poor people, but they are not the people coming to the United States.” According to Henley and Partners, a consultancy, more dollar millionaires (about 7,500) emigrated from India last year than from anywhere but China and Russia.

Indeed Indian migrants are relatively wealthy even in the countries they have moved to. Indians are the highest-earning migrant group in America, with a median household income of almost $150,000 per year. That is double the national average and well ahead of Chinese migrants, with a median household income of over $95,000. In Australia the median household income among Indian migrants is close to $87,000 per year, compared with an average of roughly $62,000 across all households and about $58,000 among the Chinese-born.

Read more of our package on India:

  • Joe Biden and Narendra Modi are drawing their countries closer
  • America is courting India in part for its growing economic clout
  • India's foreign minister on ties with America, China and Russia
  • On defence, America and India edge closer together
  • Banyan: Narendra Modi is the world's most popular leader

The might of the Indian diaspora is increasingly on display at the pinnacle of business and the apex of government. Devesh Kapur and Aditi Mahesh at Johns Hopkins University totted up the number of people with Indian roots in top jobs, including those born in India and those whose forebears were. They identified 25 chief executives at S&P 500 companies of Indian descent, up from 11 a decade ago. Given the large number of Indian-origin executives in other senior positions at these companies, that figure is almost sure to rise further.

Up at the top

It is only recently that Indians abroad have begun to win such prestigious posts. Meghnad Desai was one of a handful of Indians at American universities when he won a scholarship to the University of Pennsylvania in 1960. He points out that the diaspora wasn't rich or powerful back then. “I remember people saying: 'Americans will never have Indians in top positions',” he recalls.

In the tech industry, Vinod Khosla, co-founder of Sun Microsystems, a computer-maker, explains that it was difficult for Indian entrepreneurs to raise money in 1980s America. “You were people with a funny accent and a hard-to-pronounce name and you had to pass a higher bar,” he says. Now Adobe, Alphabet, Google's corporate parent, IBM and Microsoft are all led by people of Indian descent. The deans at three of the five leading business schools, including Harvard Business School, are as well.

The Indian diaspora is also thriving in the world of politics and policy. The Johns Hopkins researchers counted 19 people of Indian heritage in Britain's House of Commons, including the prime minister, Rishi Sunak. They identified six in the Australian parliament and five in America's Congress. America's vice-president, Kamala Harris, was raised by her Tamil Indian mother. And Ajay Banga, born in Pune in western India, was chosen to lead the World Bank last month after running MasterCard for more than a decade.

The Chinese diaspora is the only other group with comparable influence around the world. An analysis by The Economist conducted as the covid-19 pandemic began estimated that more than three-quarters of the total $369bn of billionaire wealth in South-East Asia is controlled by huaqiao , a Mandarin term for the ethnic Chinese who are citizens of other countries.

In Europe and across North America the picture is somewhat different. There are fewer bosses of Chinese descent running S&P 500 companies than there are bosses of Indian descent. That may be because many of the most successful business types choose to stay in China, working for Chinese funds and investing in fast-growing Chinese businesses, like Xiaomi, a smartphone-maker, Baidu, an internet-search giant, and ByteDance, the Beijing-based parent company of TikTok, a social-media app crammed with videos.

Indian rules

Moreover, as America drifts towards a new cold war with China, Westerners increasingly see the country as an enemy. The covid-19 pandemic, which began in the Chinese city of Wuhan, probably made matters worse. Recent scares—the appearance of a Chinese spy-balloon over America in late January, and reports this month that China had reached an agreement with the Cuban government to set up an electronic-eavesdropping station on the island—have further sharpened the image of China as a hostile adversary. In a recent survey of Americans' attitudes by Gallup, a pollster, 84% of respondents said they viewed China mostly or very unfavourably. On India, only 27% of people asked said they held the same negative views.

This mistrust of China percolates through policy. Huawei, a Chinese telecoms-equipment manufacturer suspected in the past of embargo-busting and of being a conduit for Chinese government spying, has been banned in America. Some European countries are following suit. Stringent reviews of foreign investments in American companies on national-security grounds openly target Chinese money in Silicon Valley. Individuals found to be doing China's bidding, including one ex-Harvard professor, have been punished. Indian firms do not face such scrutiny.

The Indian government, by contrast, has been—at least until Mr Modi and his Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party ( BJP ) took over—filled with people whose view of the world had been at least partly shaped by an education in the West. India's first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, studied at Cambridge. Mr Modi's predecessor, Manmohan Singh, went to both Oxford and Cambridge. When Mr Modi took the reins, the central bank was run by Raghuram Rajan, a former IMF official and professor at the University of Chicago.

India's claims to be a democracy steeped in liberal values help its diaspora integrate more readily in the West. The diaspora in turn then binds India to the West. A stunning example of this came in 2005, when America struck an agreement that, in effect, recognised India as a nuclear power, despite its refusal to sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (along with Pakistan and Israel). Lobbying and fundraising by Indian-Americans helped push the deal through Congress.

The Indian diaspora gets involved in politics back in India, too. Ahead of the 2014 general election, when Mr Modi first swept to power, one estimate suggests more than 8,000 overseas Indians from Britain and America flew to India to join his campaign. Hordes of others used text messages and social media to turn out BJP votes from afar. They contributed unknown sums of money to the campaign.

It is Mr Modi himself that interests many. When he visited Australia in May the highlight of his trip was a rally for the Indian diaspora held at a 21,000-seat stadium fit for a rock star. In his speech, Mr Modi celebrated Indian-Australians as a “living bridge” between the two countries. Courting the diaspora is likely once again to be at the top of Mr Modi's agenda during his forthcoming state visit to America. His previous audiences with Indian-Americans include a rally for 18,000 at Madison Square Garden in New York in 2014 and a “Howdy Modi” rally for 50,000 in Houston back in 2019.

Away from any crowds, Joe Biden will play host to talks with Mr Modi on June 22nd. The pair will discuss their countries' “commitment to a free, open, prosperous and secure Indo-Pacific”, among several other topics. The discussions may be difficult. Under Mr Modi, India's ties to the West have been tested. Reasserting its status as a non-aligned power, India has refused to condemn Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and stocked up on cheap Russian oil and fertiliser. India has talked loudly of promoting the interests of developing countries as chair of the G20 forum this year. It is also an important voice in the BRICS grouping, a forum which includes Brazil, Russia, China and South Africa alongside India. The club is considering whether to let Saudi Arabia and Iran join.

Mutually assured attraction

At home, officials spew reams of nationalist rhetoric that pleases right-wing Hindu hotheads. And liberal freedoms have come under attack. In March Rahul Gandhi, who is the leader of the opposition Congress party, was disqualified from parliament on a spurious defamation charge after an Indian court convicted him of criminal defamation. Meanwhile journalists are harassed and their offices raided by the authorities.

Mr Nye of Harvard warns that the chauvinist brand of Hindu nationalism Mr Modi is pushing in India puts the country's reputation at risk. Next year's elections are likely to see rising religious tensions and a further erosion of democratic norms. “India likes to boast that it is the largest democracy in the world,” Mr Nye says. “To the extent that it doesn't live up to that, it hurts Indian soft power.”

But overseas Indians help limit the damage and ensure neither India nor the West gives up on the other. Mr Modi knows he cannot afford to lose their support and that forcing hyphenated Indians to pick sides is out of the question. At a time when China and its friends want to face down a world order set by its rivals, it is vital for the West to keep India on-side. Despite its backsliding, it remains invaluable—much like its migrants. ■

; Mon, 12 Jun 2023 19:19:16 GMT /content/feke2dpgf157ogj72ean5tbjkj24vikc https://www.economist.com/international/2023/06/12/indias-diaspora-is-bigger-and-more-influential-than-any-in-history Should you send your children to private school?

E TON COLLEGE can boast of educating more than a third of Britain's 57 prime ministers over its 583 years. Less impressive is the fact that the number of its pupils winning places at the universities of Oxford or Cambridge fell by more than half between 2014 and the 2021-2022 school year. Some parents pick private schools in the hope that their kids will benefit from more attention or less bullying. Others bet that these institutions will lead to a better education, higher grades and a place at a venerable university. But soaring costs and changing university admissions policies are prompting discussion of whether the crests and crenellations are worth it.

In many rich countries, traditional private schooling is in decline. Across 30-odd members of the OECD , a club of mostly wealthy countries, the share of children in schools that get less than half their funding from government fell from about 8% in 2000 to some 5% in 2018. Private schools in Britain and America have fared better, and the debate over them remains particularly politically charged in both countries.

Recent evidence suggests that for most privately schooled children in Britain and those who attend elite private institutions in America, the advantages of an expensive education remain robust. The benefits are probably bigger in America than they are in Britain, at least for pupils sitting in the swankiest private classrooms. That is because their alumni continue to enjoy access to the best universities at rates which would cause a furore in the old country. That might surprise anyone who assumes that American society is less ridden by class than British society.

Private schools in Britain serve around 6.5% of kids, about the same share as they did in the 1960s. (Hockey sticks and rice pudding appeal across the ages.) America's ones teach about 9% of children, a share that had held steady for a decade by the time of the covid-19 pandemic. In America about 75% of private-schoolers go to institutions with religious affiliations (a big chunk of which operate on fees that are similar to, or less than, per-pupil funding in government schools). But that country also has an exclusive subset of schools, often called “independent” schools, which most closely mimic fee-paying ones in Britain. These educate less than 2% of American youngsters.

Costs in Britain are among the highest in the world. A family there can expect to cough up more than £16,000 ($20,000) a year to put one child through a private day school. That is three times what they were paying in the 1980s; it is around half the median household income in Britain, whereas it was once one-fifth. Fees in America are lower on average, but also rocketed by 60% in the first decade of this century, according to the most recent good government data. The most snooty schools bill parents on average $28,000 each year for a day pupil.

Measuring what benefits flow from these outlays matters both to critics of private schooling—who accuse posh schools of perpetuating elites—and to those who pay for it. At first glance, the pay-offs are clear: all around the rich world privately educated pupils do better in exams, go to better universities and end up with better-paid jobs. But some of that success derives from advantages outside the classroom, such as having wealthy, encouraging or intelligent parents. Understanding the boost from private education involves comparing pupils' fortunes with those of otherwise similar peers in government schools. Good research of this sort is easiest to find in Britain.

Getting the abacus out

By the time they turn 25 Britons with private education earn 17% more than other workers from similar homes, according to a study from 2015. The pay premium widens by the age of 42, according to earlier research, to around 21% for women and 35% for men. In part this is because privately schooled people are more likely to enter high-earning professions, such as finance. Alumni networks may help in this, but peer pressure and parental expectations probably play a big role, too.

A larger reason for higher incomes is because private-schoolers get more and better academic qualifications than they otherwise would. They enjoy a “modest” boost in test scores when compared with children from similar homes who enroll in government classrooms, reckons Francis Green at University College London. This advantage accumulates with every additional year they spend in private schooling. One study finds that the edge they enjoy by the time they are 18 is roughly the equivalent of moving from grades of AAB to AAA (school-leavers on England's academic track commonly take nationally standardised exams in three subjects).

The critical point is that even a modest boost in results can have a big effect on the size of additional earnings. That is because better grades might secure a pupil a slot at a more prestigious university than they would have gone to otherwise, or a slot at a university at all. In 2021 more than half of privately educated pupils who started a degree in Britain attended one of the 24 “Russell Group” universities (a club that includes most of the best ones). Such pupils are more likely to spend their last years at school studying the tough, traditional subjects that very selective universities most want to see on applications. They are also more likely to get extra help so as to ace interviews and admissions tests.

Private-schoolers no longer nab quite such unfair shares of top university places as they once did. They comprise around 18% of all pupils aged 16-19 in England, as well as about 25% of all those with top grades in school-leavers' exams. Last year they were 20% of new undergraduates at Russell Group universities.

In 2016 about 6% of all private-schoolers who began a degree in Britain won places at the universities of Oxford or Cambridge; that share has since fallen to about 4% (it is around 2% for those from government schools). Last year private-schoolers made up 32% and 27% of the pair's new British undergraduates, down from 43% and 39% a decade before. This shift has rocked the handful of elite private schools which once sent hordes of pupils to the two universities.

Picking apart the benefits of private education in America is difficult, because its schools are a more motley bunch than Britain's. Since religion is banned from government schools, many pious parents pick private classes for reasons other than academic performance alone. Overall, evidence to suggest that America's private-schoolers learn more than they would if they went to government schools is less secure than it is in Britain.

A study published in 2018 by two academics at the University of Virginia, Robert Pianta and Arya Ansari, analysed the test scores of 1,000 children who were born in the 1990s. It found that by age 15 the ones who attended American private schools were getting no better grades, after adjusting for their backgrounds. There is not much good research, however, singling out the extra benefits rich children gain from attending America's subset of “independent” schools. But it is reasonable to think that they boost a child's prospects by at least as much as their British cousins.

America's universities welcome those from grand schools with open arms. In 2021 James Murphy of Education Reform Now, a think-tank in Washington, DC, collected data from 35 of America's highest-ranked universities and liberal-arts colleges. He found that on average about 34% of their new undergraduates were educated in private high schools (see chart). That is astonishing given that the private sector educates just 8.5% of American high-schoolers. Pupils from “independent” schools do brilliantly. The most recently published data suggest they made up about one-third of new undergraduates at Dartmouth and more than a quarter at Princeton. “Legacy” preference, whereby the relatives of alumni get a leg-up in admissions, may explain some of this. Nothing so brazenly unfair happens at British universities.

Green lawns and greenbacks

Money helps, too. Whereas English universities charge every domestic student the same tuition fees (though those from abroad pay more), America's best universities vary the cost according to means. This allows exceptional pupils from poor backgrounds to study for little or nothing. But it also gives universities good reason to keep in with dependable “feeder” schools, full of clever pupils with ample wealth.

It follows that Britain's private schools are pointing more of their leavers overseas. Last year about 6% of those who went to university chose to study abroad, up from 4% in 2016. America is the most popular destination. Its universities demand top grades, says Barnaby Lenon of the Independent School Council, which represents British private schools. But he adds that they also value non-academic achievements, such as those obtained through extra-curricular activities of a kind that private schools try hard to provide.

The edge enjoyed by private-schoolers is much less discussed in America than it is in Britain, in part because questions of race, rather than class, tend to take centre stage in debates about university admissions. Political battles that have broken out over the teaching of race, sex and history are benefiting private providers, in part because states are choosing to put money into private “school-choice” programmes. These involve local governments paying for some private-school places (commonly only for poor children and usually in the cheapest kinds of private institutions).

America may be on the verge of change, however. Imminent rulings from its Supreme Court could ban the use of affirmative action in university admissions. And if colleges and universities can no longer boost applicants from underrepresented minority groups, the advantages enjoyed by posh pupils may receive greater scrutiny. Private schools in Britain face a bumpy ride, too. The Labour Party, which looks likely to win power at elections due in the next 18 months, talks of abolishing private schools' charitable status and stripping them of tax breaks. That could cause tuition fees to jump. Meanwhile, the paths to Oxford and Cambridge will keep narrowing. Expect a growing gang of Brits to head across the Atlantic. ■

I N RECENT DAYS Ron DeSantis, Florida's governor and Donald Trump's chief rival for the Republican nomination, chose to announce his bid for the White House via Twitter. The live audio event, hosted by the social network's owner, Elon Musk, descended into farce as Twitter's servers struggled to cope with the few hundred thousand listeners who had tuned in. When he could be heard, Mr DeSantis said he had decided to announce on the platform because, unlike the “legacy media”, Twitter is a “beacon of free speech”.

The debate about who can say what online is again heating up globally. Twitter, the favoured network of politicians and the press, is under the mercurial new management of Mr Musk, a self-declared free-speech absolutist who has restored the accounts of previously banned users such as Mr Trump. Meta, a larger rival, is reportedly preparing a text-based network of its own, to be launched this summer. Social-media platforms face a test over the next 18 months as America's presidential election approaches, one of the world's great festivals of online bile and misinformation.

Into this fray step politicians and judges with regulatory proposals. With Congress deadlocked, America's state legislatures and its courts are drawing new lines around the limits of speech. In Europe legislatures have gone further. These moves are inspiring governments in less democratic parts of the world to write new rules of their own. What can be said and heard online is under scrutiny.

Policing the online public square is a daunting task. Things have calmed down a bit since Mr Trump left office and covid-19—and the associated wave of disinformation—died down, but in 2022 the world's three largest social-media platforms—Facebook and Instagram, owned by Meta, and YouTube, owned by Google—removed or blocked 11.4bn posts, videos and user comments. Most are zapped by automated filters, but Meta and Google also employ more than 40,000 content-reviewers between them.

Most of this housekeeping is uncontroversial: 90% of the posts that Facebook, the largest network, took down last year were simply spam. But many moderation decisions are hard (see chart). In the latest quarter, Facebook removed or blocked 10.7m posts that it deemed hate speech and 6.9m that it considered bullying, both concepts where there is room for disagreement. To take one recent dilemma, Meta recently ordered a review of whether it has been overzealous in its policing of the Arabic word shaheed , which is generally translated as “martyr” but whose meaning can change in different contexts. The platforms have mostly been left to resolve such quandaries by themselves.

Now, however, politicians are stepping in. In America Democrats and Republicans agree that social networks are doing a lousy job of moderation, and that it is time to change Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, which shields online platforms from liability for content posted by users (with exceptions such as content linked to sex trafficking). But they disagree completely on what to do about it.

Democrats, who accuse tech billionaires of stoking rage and misinformation for clicks, want platforms to remove more content. Republicans, who think woke California busybodies are gagging conservatives, want them to remove less. (By a ratio of three to one, voters suspect tech firms of favouring liberal viewpoints over conservative ones, according to the Pew Research Centre, an American think-tank.) The result is congressional deadlock.

The Supreme Court has had the chance to tinker with Section 230. But on May 18th, in rulings on two similar cases involving YouTube and Twitter, which had hosted content uploaded by terrorists, it declined to alter the status quo, rejecting the idea that online platforms have liability for crimes their users commit. NetChoice, a tech lobby group, described the decision as a “huge win for free speech on the internet”. Section 230 looks safe for now.

With no luck at the federal level, reformers on left and right are focusing on the states. Last year California passed a law forcing tech companies to collect less user information on children, among other things. Several states have passed or proposed laws requiring those under 18 to get parental permission before using social media. On May 17th Montana banned TikTok altogether, over its Chinese ownership (TikTok is suing and is expected to win).

States of denial

Most controversially, in 2021 Florida and Texas, both Republican-controlled, passed laws restricting social networks' ability to moderate political speech. Courts have upheld Texas's law and struck down Florida's, paving the way for a return to the Supreme Court, which is expected to take up the cases later this year. “If the court opens up the door to regulation in this space, many [states] will jump at the opportunity,” says Evelyn Douek of Stanford University.

They will have two transatlantic models to follow. Passed in July 2022, the EU ’s Digital Services Act ( DSA ) will kick in next year. Britain's Online Safety Bill , four years in the making, is expected to be enacted later this year. Both take a different approach from America's. Rather than altering who has liability for online content (the issue at the heart of the Section 230 debate), they force platforms to do a kind of due diligence, to keep bad content to a minimum.

Europe's DSA requires online platforms to set up complaint-handling processes and demands that they tell users how their algorithms work, allowing them to change the recommendations they receive. Smaller platforms, defined as those with fewer than 45m users in the eu , will be let off some of these obligations to stop them from drowning in red tape (some larger rivals warn that this could make them a haven for harmful material). For those big enough to qualify for full oversight, the DSA represents “a significant financial burden”, says Florian Reiling of Clifford Chance, a law firm. There is grumbling in Washington that of the 19 platforms so far earmarked by the EU for the most intensive scrutiny, only one—Zalando, a German e-commerce site—is European.

Twitter, which has cut its staff by about 80% since Mr Musk took over in October, may be one of those that struggles to meet the DSA ’s requirements. Mr Musk seems to have taken over from Mark Zuckerberg, Meta's boss, as social media's greatest villain in the eyes of some. On May 26th Thierry Breton, a European commissioner, tweeted that Twitter had left the EU ’s voluntary code of practice against disinformation, adding what sounded like a threat: “You can run but you can't hide.”

Britain's parallel legislative effort is shaping up to be more far-reaching. The Online Safety Bill was conceived in 2019 after the suicide of a 14-year-old who had binged on algorithmically recommended depressive material. Four prime ministers later, the text of the bill has almost doubled in length. An American tech firm dubs it “one of the most complex bills we face anywhere in the world”.

It goes further than the EU in its loosely worded requirement for platforms to proactively screen material. The larger social networks already check videos for matches with known child-abuse content. But subtler crimes, such as incitement to violence, are harder to detect automatically. The scale of some platforms—YouTube uploads 500 hours of video per minute—means that a strict requirement to pre-screen content could throttle the amount of new material uploaded.

As in America, British conservatives worry about the over-moderation of right-wing views. The bill therefore imposes a duty to ensure that moderation “[applies] in the same way to a wide diversity of political opinion”. Similarly, the EU has promised that it will provide “protection for media against unjustified online content removal” as part of its forthcoming European Media Freedom Act, a response to crackdowns on the press in members states such as Hungary and Poland.

The most controversial part of Britain's bill, which required platforms to identify content that is “legal but harmful” (eg, material that encourages eating disorders), has been dropped where adults are concerned. But there remains a duty to limit its availability to children, which in turn implies the need for widespread age checks. Tech firms say they can guess users' ages from their search history and mouse movements, but that a strict duty to verify users' ages would threaten anonymity.

Some suspect that their real objection is the price. “I don't think 'It costs money and is hard' is an excuse,” says Keily Blair, chief operations officer of OnlyFans, a porn-centric platform which checks the age of its users and doesn't see why others shouldn't do the same. Yet some platforms are adamant: the Wikimedia Foundation, which runs Wikipedia, says it has no intention of verifying users' ages.

The stricter the rules in jurisdictions such as Britain or the eu , the likelier tech companies will be to opt to offer different services there, rather than to apply the same rules worldwide. Some may even quit. WhatsApp, a Meta-owned messaging app, says it is unwilling to break its end-to-end encryption to meet a requirement in Britain's bill that companies must scan private messages for child abuse. It may not come to that: the bill would let Ofcom demand the data only in cases where it determined that such a measure was proportionate. Still, threats to up sticks are becoming more common. On May 24th Sam Altman, the head of Open AI , said he would consider leaving the eu if its regulation of artificial intelligence went too far. (He later rowed back his remarks.)

网络效应

无论英国或欧盟是否充分利用其新权力，它们都为可能压迫性地使用这些权力的国家树立了先例。公民自由组织电子前沿基金会表示，英国的这项法案提议将违反规定的公司高管关进监狱，这是“世界各地镇压的蓝图”。一位美国高管讽刺称，英国自称在科技领域“世界领先”的说法只有在英国为非民主国家通过自己的压制性法律开辟道路的意义上才是正确的。

他们几乎不需要鼓励。土耳其在最近的选举期间命令 Twitter 审查信息；言论自由的狂热爱好者马斯克先生答应了。巴西提出了一项“假新闻法”，将对未能识别错误信息的社交网络进行惩罚。它以欧洲立法为蓝本，被称为“热带地区的DSA ”。印度将于 6 月发布一项互联网监管法案，据报道，如果平台不同意按照指示识别和追踪用户，则该法案将要求平台对用户的内容承担责任。

英国和欧盟提案的国际影响正在影响美国的辩论。美国网络公司 Cloudflare 的负责人马修·普林斯 (Matthew Prince) 表示：“无论你认为社交网络对美国政治的腐蚀有多大，它们都对其他违背美国利益的政权造成了令人难以置信的不稳定。 ” ■
